properties.name: Sherlock Holmes
properties.description:
Kursaal
Before the De La Warr Pavilion opened in 1935, this was Bexhill's principal place of entertainment and where Treville set up his Franco British Film Company.

properties.name: Sherlock Holmes
properties.description:
Sidley
Auckland House was used for some of films exteriors, it has since been demolished and replaced with apartments.

properties.name: It's a Bet
properties.description:
Galley Hill
In the background of this shot you can see Sackville Lodge, a prominent bungalow (demolished 1968), back when the road was unpaved.

properties.name: Double Confession
properties.description:
De La Warr Pavilion
The internal shots may look like they filmed in the DLWP, however is actually a film set - notice how the fictional staircase spirals up in the opposite direction.

properties.name: Double Confession
properties.description:
East Parade
Notice the large chimney behind Galley Hill at what was once Glyne Gap Gas Works.

properties.name: Quiet Woman
properties.description:
The Star Inn
A clear look at the frontage of the public house and Sluice Road. Filming was made in Rye for the harbour areas.

properties.name: Other Womens Lives: Talking Shop
properties.description:
Sidley
Mrs Cowlard is shown cycling along Preston Road, towards her prefab at number 70 (a street directory confirms this the family's address). Today this would be houses numbered 28-29 (built in the early 60s).

properties.name: Other Womens Lives: Talking Shop
properties.description:
Old Town
The High Street is shown and a pet shop occupies half of what is now Trafalgar House. A later beach scene is possibly around the Cooden area.

properties.name: The ABC Murders
properties.description:
Bexhill Beach
In the 1991 version, filming was mostly done around and near The Colonnade. In the 2018 adaptation, East Parade and around the Sailing Club was chosen.

properties.name: Piece of Cake
properties.description:
Cooden Beach Station.
This was the original entrance hall and ticket office, it was converted in the early 2000's to a convenience store.

properties.name: A Set of Six
properties.description:
18 Sackville Road
This was the location of the Bexhill-on-Sea Observer offices until July 2012. There are also various scenes of Bexhill's beach and promenade featured throughout the episode.

properties.name: Richard III
properties.description:
The Colonnade
Its dramatic transformation was to match the Indian style of Brighton Royal Pavilion (the royal family's seaside retreat in the film), which obviously doesn't have a seaside garden.

properties.name: Never Let Me Go
properties.description:
De La Warr Parade
The rear of Marine Mansions was transformed to look like the front of the building with a number of doors and garden gates swapped out.

properties.name: Keane: Sovereign Light Café
properties.description:
West Parade
Although mostly set on West Parade, there are some shots of East Parade with a nod to motor racing history and of course the Bathing Station café appears on the album cover.
